summary: James W. McCord, Jr. was a CIA employee whose personnel file details his career assignments from 1948 to 1964. He was involved in the Office of Security and was reassigned in 1965. He received an Honor and Merit Award for his work improving the Agency's Audio-countermeasures Program, specifically in the development of a new fluoroscopic scanning technique for detecting clandestine microphones. McCord's file also contains documents related to his employment and involuntary retirement from the CIA in 1970, including performance reviews and commendations.
significance: The provided documents do not explicitly mention James W. McCord, Jr.'s involvement in the JFK assassination context. His significance is primarily related to his career within the CIA, particularly his work in security and audio-countermeasures.
